file_metadata.title: Editorial: Interplay Between Ion Channels, the Nervous System, and Embryonic Development

chunks.text: Ion channels play crucial roles in maintaining ion gradients, membrane potentials, and rapid signaling in cells. Recent research has revealed their critical involvement in the development, degeneration, and regeneration of both excitable and non-excitable cells and organs.
chunks.topic: Ion channels in development and regeneration
chunks.chunk_summary: Ion channels are essential for cellular processes and play critical roles in development, degeneration, and regeneration.

chunks.text: Examples of ion channels with associated channelopathies that have revealed such novel roles include Kv3.1, Kir2.1, Kir7.1, and GIRK2. Understanding these non-conventional roles of ion channels will provide insights into the mechanisms underlying development, degeneration, and regeneration, and offer new therapeutic approaches targeting bioelectric states for regenerative applications and cancer treatment.
chunks.chunk_summary: Studying channelopathies can reveal novel roles of ion channels and lead to new therapeutic strategies.

chunks.text: This Research Topic focuses on the non-conventional roles of ion channels in development, disease, and repair of excitable and non-excitable tissues. The articles cover a wide spectrum of issues in the field, including channelopathies, the role of Kir2.1 in bone development, the ontogeny of ion currents in developing nervous systems, bioelectric prepatterns in brain development, and the origin of the invariant structure of the C. elegans embryo.
chunks.chunk_summary: This Research Topic explores the diverse roles of ion channels in development, disease, and repair across various tissues.

chunks.text: Tyagi et al. review the diverse range of channelopathy symptoms arising from mutations in the human gene CACNAIA, which encodes the calcium channel Cav2.1. They emphasize the need to determine both the direct effect of the mutation on channel function and its effect in a physiological context, highlighting the advantages of the zebrafish as a model system.
chunks.chunk_summary: The zebrafish model is valuable for studying the mechanistic basis of calcium channelopathies and the broader impact of ion channel mutations.

chunks.text: Ozekin et al. focus on the ion channel Kir2.1 and its role in bone development, particularly craniofacial morphogenesis. This ion channel has also been implicated in other developmental processes, such as Drosophila wing development. The review highlights the importance of "developmental bioelectricity" in the context of the embryo and the effects of teratogens on ion channels.
chunks.chunk_summary: Kir2.1 plays a crucial role in bone development, and its study highlights the importance of developmental bioelectricity.

chunks.text: Goyal et al. review studies on the ontogeny of ion currents in developing nervous systems, highlighting the roles of ion channels in neural tube formation and the molecular mechanisms downstream of their function that guide cell proliferation and differentiation. The regulation of morphogenetic and cellular processes by electrical activity is critical for vertebrate nervous system development.
chunks.topic: Ion channels in nervous system development
chunks.chunk_summary: Ion channels and electrical activity regulate morphogenetic and cellular processes crucial for vertebrate nervous system development.

chunks.text: Pai et al. study the role of bioelectric prepatterns in establishing the correct size and shape of the frog embryo brain. They show that up-regulation of context-sensitive channels, such as HCN2, sharpens voltage boundaries and rescues the normal bioelectric prepattern, restoring gene expression, brain morphogenesis, and cognitive function despite teratogens.
chunks.chunk_summary: Bioelectric prepatterns are essential for brain development, and manipulating ion channels like HCN2 can rescue developmental defects caused by teratogens.

chunks.text: Alicea reviews the cell and molecular data on the origin of the invariant structure of the C. elegans embryo. They propose a model of synaptic connectivity that reveals design principles of electrical networks, which helps understand the life and function of this important model system. Characterizing these earliest events of cooperation between genetic and biophysical layers is critical for understanding the ontogeny of bioelectric gradients and evolutionary dynamics.
chunks.chunk_summary: Studying the C. elegans embryo reveals design principles of electrical networks and the interplay between genetic and biophysical layers in development.

chunks.text: These studies reveal the emerging roles of ion channel activity in health and disease, contributing to a field with implications for basic knowledge about information processing by biophysical mechanisms in living tissue and driving biomedical applications based on modulating ionic communication.
chunks.chunk_summary: The study of ion channels has broad implications for understanding biophysical information processing and developing biomedical applications.

chunks.text: ML and AR wrote the manuscript and approved the final version for publication. Both authors contributed to the article and approved the submitted version.
chunks.chunk_summary: ML and AR co-authored the manuscript and approved its publication.
